name: Poindexter

topics.topic_text: Want to play a hand of Caravan?
topics.response_text: A fascinating proposition. Naturally, my considerable genius makes me a master of the game, so try not to be disappointed if you lose miserably.
I am unsurprised regarding your appalling lack of talent. Perhaps you'd care to try another hand? After all, you can only improve.
Well now, this is an unexpected variable. You really must let me challenge you to a rematch, so I can analyze what passes for your strategy.

topics.topic_text: I'm all done playing for now.
topics.response_text: As you wish. Once you've salved your battered ego, perhaps you'll make another go of it.
Very well. I would wish you luck, but of course peerless intellect is all that matters here.
While I have already internalized the new skills we have discussed, I feel as though my solution was nevertheless more practical.

topics.topic_text: I think you'll find that the Misfits' records are now much improved.
topics.response_text: You actually did it? My friend, I am without doubt a genius, but I must say, you've given me a run for my money. Bravo. Bravo.

topics.topic_text: How'd a guy like you end up in the Army?
topics.response_text: It's a simple idea: the Army offers fiscal security and generous benefits at the cost of substantial personal risk - if you're on the front line.
To what purpose? It's highly unlikely you'd understand anything I'd say.

topics.topic_text: Are you in charge around here?
topics.response_text: In a strictly official capacity, no.
I suppose if you must stick with your narrow, parochial view of "in charge," then yes, it's a no. Are we done?

topics.topic_text: I wonder if anyone else would share that sentiment.
topics.response_text: Genius is seldom appreciated in its own time.

topics.topic_text: Great, maybe you can help me get this squad working together!
topics.response_text: [FAILED] Why would I? If this unit improves its performance, we'll be shipped to the front lines. That's hardly conducive to living a long life.

topics.topic_text: He thinks you might respond better to someone who isn't an authority figure.
topics.response_text: This is an unexpected variable. I had hoped to coast on an easy wave of mediocrity to a cushy government pension.

topics.topic_text: I guess you don't feel so smart now, huh?
topics.response_text: Your insults are both unhelpful and unwanted. I'll thank you to keep them to yourself.
And how would you propose accomplishing such a goal?

topics.topic_text: It occurs to me that I might cheat.
I'll do it. Work is overrated anyways.
topics.response_text: Excellent! Squad readiness records can be accessed from two terminals at the resort: the main terminal in the lobby or a secure one in a back office.

topics.topic_text: Maybe I'll ask around a little more instead.
topics.response_text: As you wish; I'm sure the optimal solution will become apparent to you in time.

conversation.response_text: I somehow suspect you'll be back to converse with me later.

description:
Poindexter is a 27 year-old Caucasian (American) Male.

Private Poindexter is an NCR soldier and part of the Misfits living at Camp Golf in the Mojave Wasteland. Despite his military rank, he stands out for his distinctive appearance - thin-rimmed glasses perpetually sliding down his nose and a perpetually annoyed expression that suggests he's constantly burdened by the intellectual inferiority of those around him.

Poindexter's Personality: Self-serving know-it-all with an inflated ego and thinly veiled contempt for his fellow troopers. To himself, he's a certified genius whom everyone at Camp looks up to. To everyone else, he's an annoying smart-ass who cannot follow orders. He's motivated entirely by self-interest and views military service as a means to an end rather than a calling.

Poindexter's Backstory: Born and raised in the relative safety of New California Republic territory, Poindexter always considered himself intellectually superior to his peers. Rather than pursuing a meaningful career, he saw the NCR Army as the perfect opportunity to gain benefits and prestige with minimal risk. He deliberately performs just well enough to avoid being deployed to the front lines, riding the 'mediocrity gradient' to eventually secure a comfortable desk job as a 'veteran.' His assignment to Camp Golf and the Misfits unit was seen by him as a temporary setback in his otherwise brilliant career plan.
